item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

I knew there was a problem I ran across using instances like that. Then when I started doing a procedure on my server I remembered why.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“sini, post:47, topic:551894”]1). They DONT. There is nothing beyond planes 0-3, they just use a modulus operation to give a virtual instance where then they can sort if entities are within view by comparing the actual plane with an instance which are in multiples of 4.

2). Jesus christ, I said this in my post.

3). It isn’t I guess? But just because it isn’t bad for clipping doesn’t mean its bad for other aspects which I explained, yet again.[/quote]
Which, in my first post, I said I literally only use it for clipping. Nothing more.

Edit:
Look what I found. You said that using the construct region packet vs height X 4 is “Just a preference”:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:27, topic:551894”][quote author=sini link=topic=670810.msg4485854#msg4485854 date=1433954144]
Yeah pretty much. I still prefer the construct region packet personally.
[/quote]I think the main reason people dont do that is because you’d have to actually do a little bit of copying to get server sided clipping to work with that, whereas with the plane you wouldnt (except doing the %4 thing in a few places)[/quote]

sini:

Yeah it’s just preference.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

1). They DONT. There is nothing beyond planes 0-3, they just use a modulus operation to give a virtual instance where then they can sort if entities are within view by comparing the actual plane with an instance which are in multiples of 4.

2). Jesus christ, I said this in my post.

3). It isn’t I guess? But just because it isn’t bad for clipping doesn’t mean its bad for other aspects which I explained, yet again.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Actually, this is what I’m not understanding:

  1. Why do the maps repeat themselves every 4 heights and why should we not use them for “instancing”?

  2. Why should I construct a map that already exists for instancing?

  3. Why is it bad for CLIPPING - I’m not talking checking for any entity, I mean specifically clipping.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

It existed long before construction. Did I stutter? Does it not make sense? Because you are not understanding what I am saying.

This is what angers me about the community, you guys do not take the time to understand the underlying mechanics involved with the various important aspects of developing a server.

I’ll explain it again because you are slow

It’s not a good practice.

There are plenty of cases you need to represent a location as a unique numeric representation aka hash

This is why the construct region packet exists.

Its not about CLIPPING
Its not about if you can CHECK if an entity exists on the plane

If you follow bad practices you will eventually run into design problems. This is why we avoid bad practices at all costs unless it’s affordable to do so.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“sini, post:43, topic:551894”]Okay how many times do I have to explain this

It’s not a good practice.

There are plenty of cases you need to represent a location as a unique numeric representation aka hash

This is why the construct region packet exists.

Its not about CLIPPING
Its not about if you can CHECK if an entity exists on the plane[/quote]
I know it’s not good practice…
But why should I create a region for the player when they’re not doing anything special?
The construct region packet was for construction… You know, because people had different rooms and etc… They also had different themes…

If I want to make an “instanced” boss, where each player can fight their own boss alone, why would I construct the boss’s room (That already exists on the map) for that when I can just do height + (pID * 4)?

That is also why I specifically stated “I Use % 4 in CLIPPING” - not anything about the entity checking.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Okay how many times do I have to explain this

It’s not a good practice.

There are plenty of cases you need to represent a location as a unique numeric representation aka hash

This is why the construct region packet exists.

Its not about CLIPPING
Its not about if you can CHECK if an entity exists on the plane

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“sini, post:41, topic:551894”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=670810.msg4489703#msg4489703 date=1436826027]

You need at least 14 bits to represent x and y so at MOST you could have 4 bits dedicated to the plane. But if you’re using instances for housing you’d need up to, 2048 planes (maximum players) which requires at least 11 bits.

It doesn’t work. And yes you have to take into account hashing for various different purposes.
[/quote]Im just trying to think of where you’d need to hash the players location in a place where you couldnt % 3 it, and I can’t think of any off the top of my head.

Because its not a TRUE plane, and if you had to use a hash to be specific about the TRUE location then you couldn’t use the hash. You lose information.

Excuse the typo its % 4, since there are 4 planes.

It’s a bad practice.

Say you had a mapping of a positions hash (30 bits) to an object, if you had an object on plane 4 it would be represented as plane 0 and therefore would not be a true representation of where the object actually is. And in this situation its important because you will be overwriting objects where ones should exist.[/quote]
Not to but in on the conversation…
But I actually use the % 4 for clipping in “Player instanced” regions (Quotes because the “instance” is literally just height + (playerId * 4))
Since the region is the exact same (objects and all that shit) - the clipping doesn’t change.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:40, topic:551894”][quote author=sini link=topic=670810.msg4489701#msg4489701 date=1436822216]
You need at least 14 bits to represent x and y so at MOST you could have 4 bits dedicated to the plane. But if you’re using instances for housing you’d need up to, 2048 planes (maximum players) which requires at least 11 bits.

It doesn’t work. And yes you have to take into account hashing for various different purposes.
[/quote]Im just trying to think of where you’d need to hash the players location in a place where you couldnt % 3 it, and I can’t think of any off the top of my head.[/quote]

Because its not a TRUE plane, and if you had to use a hash to be specific about the TRUE location then you couldn’t use the hash. You lose information.

Excuse the typo its % 4, since there are 4 planes.

It’s a bad practice.

Say you had a mapping of a positions hash (30 bits) to an object, if you had an object on plane 4 it would be represented as plane 0 and therefore would not be a true representation of where the object actually is. And in this situation its important because you will be overwriting objects where ones should exist.

Read full topic

It doesn’t work. And yes you have to take into account hashing for various different purposes.[/quote]Im just trying to think of where you’d need to hash the players location in a place where you couldnt % 3 it, and I can’t think of any off the top of my head.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

You need at least 14 bits to represent x and y so at MOST you could have 4 bits dedicated to the plane. But if you’re using instances for housing you’d need up to, 2048 planes (maximum players) which requires at least 11 bits.

It doesn’t work. And yes you have to take into account hashing for various different purposes.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sini, post:37, topic:551894”]I just remembered why using

plane % 3

Is bad. Hashing! Because if you’re using 2 bits dedicated to the plane then you’re destroying the plane information when you may want to dissect the hash. Bad practice. No bueno.[/quote]Then don’t use only 2 bits to hash the plane information server sided I can’t even actually think of a situation where that would be relevant though, where would you be hashing the location in such a place that you couldn’t take into account more than 2 bits?

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

I just remembered why using

plane % 3

Is bad. Hashing! Because if you’re using 2 bits dedicated to the plane then you’re destroying the plane information when you may want to dissect the hash. Bad practice. No bueno.

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

I’m not saying it’s more expensive, I’m saying that it takes the check away from the update protocol. If it doesn’t matter what height they’re on then what’s the point in checking it. Since you’re removing it the update process per player to update is a little smaller but ofcourse you’re going to do more updating (for the same reason) so it’s actually more costly.

My bad

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

Cres:

Sini, I think it requires even less processing server-side because now you don’t have to check the height levels and you could make it prioritize your z level first before updating people on different height levels

ummmmm since when is performing a simple check more expensive than performing the entire update protocol?

Read full topic

item.title: [SHOWOFF] Multi plane rendering
item.dc:creator: @Death_Style Death Style
item.description:
@Death_Style wrote:

npcs don’t render on different planes?

items are static. new ones won’t appear and old ones won’t disappear unless you hit that plane again. or at least that’s how runescape did it before recent years

Read full topic
